properties.name: Amy's Park Blue Trail
properties.description:
Easy; wide trail follows an old logging road.
Access from northern trail head, or #FC4C02 or Red Trails.
Educational signage along trail.

properties.name: Amy's Park #FC4C02 Trail
properties.description:
Easy/moderate; loop includes a short steep section.
Access from Yellow or Blue Trails.
Educational signage along trail; views of the upper pond.

properties.name: Amy's Park Red Trail - North
properties.description:
Easy/moderate; remote trail follows edge of pond.
Access from Trout Falls Rd; heads north to connect to Blue Trail; includes
bridges and views of northern pond.
Educational signage along trail.

properties.name: Amy's Park Red Trail - North
properties.description:
Easy/moderate; remote trail follows edge of pond.
Access from Trout Falls Rd; heads north to connect to Blue Trail; includes
bridges and views of northern pond.
Educational signage along trail.

properties.name: Amy's Park Yellow Trail
properties.description:
Easy; mostly flat, includes bridges and a few short climbs.
(Section west of Trout Falls Rd to Red Trail is steep and challenging.)
Canoe/kayak access with short portage (420 feet).
Access from Main Parking Lot or second lot on Padanarum Rd.
Educational signage along trail; views of the pond, beaver lodge and dam

properties.name: Cat Mountain Red Trail
properties.description: The red trail is the most challenging trail. It drops steeply from the summit of Cat Mt. (following blazes) for 0.4 miles before it levels off for 0.25 miles, then descends again gradually for 0.35 miles to a ravine. It then undulates for 0.3 miles until it reaches Edgecomb Pond, where it turns left (west) and follows a dirt road for 0.5 miles. (Turning right takes you to Edgecomb Pond Rd and the trail to The Pinnacle.) Just past the gate, the trail turns right (north) and continues on the dirt road to the intersection with the yellow trail.

properties.name: Ed's Red Stripe Trail
properties.description:
Moderately challenging; steady ascent of 360' over 0.75 miles. Access from Trout Falls Rd, ends at a scenic overlook. Dedicated to Ed Sheridan, steward of Amy's Park and passionate explorer of the
natural world.

properties.name: Ed's Red Stripe Trail
properties.description:
Moderately challenging; steady ascent of 360' over 0.75 miles. Access from Trout Falls Rd, ends at a scenic overlook. Dedicated to Ed Sheridan, steward of Amy's Park and passionate explorer of the
natural world.

properties.name: Godwin Preserve Red Trail
properties.description: From the Padanarum Road parking area the red trail follows a logging road for 0.5 miles, with a gradual upward grade, then leaves the road for 300 feet and climbs a short, fairly steep ledge, before returning to the road. If you continue on the red trail, it follows the road gradually downhill for 0.5 miles until it reaches the corner of the preserve, which adjoins the Pole Hill Pond Forest Preserve.

properties.name: Godwin Preserve Red Trail
properties.description: From the Padanarum Road parking area the red trail follows a logging road for 0.5 miles, with a gradual upward grade, then leaves the road for 300 feet and climbs a short, fairly steep ledge, before returning to the road. If you continue on the red trail, it follows the road gradually downhill for 0.5 miles until it reaches the corner of the preserve, which adjoins the Pole Hill Pond Forest Preserve.

properties.name: Richard Hayes Phillips Trail
properties.description: The ridge trail (Richard Hayes Phillips Trail) has blue markers and runs 2.3 miles from the Thomas Mountain cabin to the summit of Cat Mountain at 1,956-feet. Footing is more difficult than the other trails and hikers should be prepared for the longer, more challenging trek.

properties.name: Richard Hayes Phillips Trail
properties.description: The ridge trail (Richard Hayes Phillips Trail) has blue markers and runs 2.3 miles from the Thomas Mountain cabin to the summit of Cat Mountain at 1,956-feet. Footing is more difficult than the other trails and hikers should be prepared for the longer, more challenging trek.

properties.name: Gull Bay Preserve Blue Trail
properties.description: From the parking area, walk a short distance following an old logging road to the preserve’s kiosk. From here the blue trail continues on the logging road uphill for less than half a mile, ending at an overlook that peeks out to Gull Bay and to the south over Lake George.

properties.name: Gull Bay Preserve Blue Trail
properties.description: From the parking area, walk a short distance following an old logging road to the preserve’s kiosk. From here the blue trail continues on the logging road uphill for less than half a mile, ending at an overlook that peeks out to Gull Bay and to the south over Lake George.

properties.name: Gull Bay Preserve Red Trail
properties.description: The #FC4C02 and yellow loops are connected by the red trail, which follows a path below and parallel to the beaver dam.  At the intersection with the yellow trail, you may also follow the red trail further north along a beaver meadow, crossing the outlet to another overlook that provides an expansive view of the ponds and wetlands. This trail climbs a steep rocky ledge; please hike with caution!   Note the damage from an illegal campfire that occurred during June 2016.

properties.name: Gull Bay Preserve Red Trail

Gull Bay Preserve Yellow Trail
properties.description: The yellow trail starts from the blue trail’s northern end and follows the pond’s western ridge to a loop through a fern-laden forest north of the pond.

properties.name: Last Great Shoreline Blue Trail
properties.description: After a short walk from the parking area to the kiosk, the blue trail gradually descends from the kiosk at an elevation of 552 feet approximately 1.20 miles southwest through the preserve to a scenic overlook that provides a west-facing view of Lake George.  The blue trail is easy to navigate, with minimal elevation change. From the overlook the trail makes a short, but steep descent to the dock.

properties.name: Last Great Shoreline Blue Trail

properties.name: Record Hill Trail
properties.description:
From the trailhead on Schwerdtfeger Road, the trail climbs moderately in a westerly direction for 0.30 miles, before turning north to ascend 665 feet over 1/2-mile to the top of Record Hill (elevation of 1,265 feet). You will note that there is a second viewing area that looks north along the lake.

For the first 0.25 miles the trail follows a right-of-way, with a fence marking the southern boundary. Please respect the adjoining landowner’s privacy and do not cross the fence.

Please note: the trail does not extend beyond the summit of Record Hill. There are no official trails to Flat Rock at this time. Do not attempt to hike westward to the summit of Anthony’s Nose; the trail has purposefully been kept away from the cliffs in order to avoid any possible disturbance of nesting peregrine falcons. Access from the water is not recommended, as it is a very steep and rocky shoreline.

properties.name: Cook Mountain Cemetery Trail
properties.description: The blue trail takes you to a cemetery that dates to the Civil War.

properties.name: Cook Mountain Ridges Trail
properties.description: The Ridges Trail ascends steeply – 680′ over 0.5-mile – then climbs more gradually for the remaining 0.6 miles to an elevation of 1,213′.  A short loop to an eastern view into Vermont is reached after 0.75 miles from its base.  Continue following The Ridges Trail to its end for a fantastic, clear view down Lake George.  Flat Rock and Anthony’s Nose can be seen on the left, and Rogers’ Rock on the right.

properties.name: Cook Mountain Yellow Trail
properties.description: Starting from the parking area and kiosk the yellow trail follows a wide flat path into the preserve. After about 0.12 miles the trail’s loop begins.  Stay straight to follow the trail another 0.4 miles along a gently climbing path (which turns into a dirt road) to its junction with the Ridges Trail, or turn right to wind along the shore of what was once an active beaver pond.  The absence of beavers resulted in a breached dam and loss of water; grasses and shrubs recolonized the pondflat, and it is slowly returning to woodland.  After about 0.2 miles, the trail joins the Ridges Trail, marked with red round disks.
